title: 113_hr5849
content: The Act may be cited as the "Paid Sick Leave Act" and requires paid sick leave. The Paid Sick Leave Act mandates that employees earn 1 hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked. This leave can be used for the employee's own illness, medical care, or to care for family members with medical needs. The Paid Sick Leave Act allows employees to take time off for domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking situations to seek medical attention, recover from injuries, or obtain services from victim organizations. The Act allows individuals to seek counseling, relocation, or legal action related to domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking. Definitions include "child" as under 18 or incapable of self-care, and "domestic violence" as specified. The term "domestic violence" is defined as per the Violence Against Women Act of 1994, with adjustments for jurisdiction. An "employee" is an individual covered under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, excluding certain cases. The term "employer" refers to specific categories including government employees, State employees, covered employees under various Acts, and Federal officers or employees. The term "employer" includes covered employers, State employees, government employees, and Federal officers or employees under specific Acts. The term "covered employer" refers to any person engaged in commerce or an industry affecting commerce who employs 15 or more employees for each working day during 20 or more calendar workweeks in the current or preceding year. The term "covered employer" includes any person who acts in the interest of an employer to employees, any successor in interest, public agencies, the Government Accountability Office, and the Library. The term "covered employer" includes public agencies, the Government Accountability Office, and the Library of Congress. A public agency is considered a person engaged in commerce or an industry affecting commerce. Commerce refers to any activity, business, or industry that could hinder commerce or the free flow of commerce. The term "person" in the context of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has the same meaning as defined in section 3(a) of the Act. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 defines terms such as employer, parent, sexual assault, and spouse in relation to employees. The Act includes references to predecessors of employers and specifies meanings based on state laws. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 defines terms related to employees, including employer, parent, sexual assault, and spouse. It also references state laws for definitions. Additionally, the Act defines "stalking" according to the Violence Against Women Act of 1994.
